data.title: Great food
data.text: First time having Indian food, and i give it two thumbs up. The place has a good atmosphere, but also a big menu for those who like variety. I had the mild rogan Josh and absolutely loved it.

data.title: Best Indian for 200 Miles Plus
data.text:
I've been west coast - east coast and over seas.  Simply put this is the best Indian Cuisine (Including Iowa City etc.) for 200 miles in diameter.  The lunch buffet is fittingly limited with only Tandoori Chicken as meat, but priced very moderately at $11.00 I believe.  The service and quality deems a minimum tip of 20% in my opinion. In regards to the Dinner menu, oh it's great and delicious.  The following is my favorite...

9. KEEMA SAMOSAS - $4.99
Two crispy pastry shells stuffed with ground lamb & a blend of aromatic spices

52. MUGHLAI KOFTA - $11.99
Tandoori seekh kebab, submerged in the creamy sauce with special herbs & spices

17. ALOO GOBHI (vegan) - $9.99
A north Indian favorite. Fresh cubes of cauliflower & potatoes sautéed with herbs & spices

16. SAAG PANEER - $9.99
A classical Indian vegetable dish made with spinach, homemade cheese & numerous spices

data.title: Best Indian food around
data.text: They know our order by heart now! We go here once a week for sure. Best food with amazing flavor. Very nice people.

data.title: Good Indian for the Quad Cities but can't compete with Chicago
data.text: The food here is good and fairly priced.The mango lassi was tasty and generously sized. Cocktails are around $6. I liked the flavor of the Bombay Mojito, but it would have been better if it was muddled as stated on the menu rather than blended (resulted in lots of small pieces of dry stem messing up the texture). The waiter said they blend because they use dried ingredients. I had a black lentil daal. It was nice, but had some other kind of beans blended in that reduced the flavor. On the whole, seasoning was authentic but slightly toned down for the midwestern palate. The vegetable appetizer platter was good and well sized for 2 people. The samosas were very nice. On a Wednesday night they seemed to be doing good business with more than half of the large dinning room full. The decor is nice, nothing memorable but what you would expect from the price range. People definitely do not dress up to go there. The location is good with free parking in the evening on the street out front and being near the art museum and river front for a nice stroll afterward. Service was good and the waiter was very patient with my older parents. Overall, I would go back here if I lived in the Quad Cities. However, if you are coming from a city with lots of Indian options, you might want to try some American food instead.

data.title: Best Indian Food Ever
data.text:
My husband and I try out Indian restaurants whenever we visit other cities and time and time again we have decided the best Indian food is right here in our backyard...at Mantra. 
The staff is wonderful, food is always delicious (even when we've brought groups of 10-15 friends with us or had my husbands birthday party catered upstairs) and they always make us feel welcome.

We bring my 16 month old to mantra regularly and the waiters there treat him with a mini mango lassi. He loves the samosas, and we order the  Chana masala for him for dinner. He loves the chickpeas and the spices! 

I love that even when our son is loud and makes a terrible mess with his rice they always say it's ok and smile. They enjoy their customers and it's obvious their customers love them. 

Of the three Indian restaurants in the QC, mantra is absolutely the best.

data.title: Nice lunch buffet
data.text: Stopped on a cross country trip for lunch buffet. The selection was a bit small, and the only meat they had was chicken, but everything was very well prepared and very tasty.  For about $10 it was a great value!

data.title: a really nice option for folks who don't crave Indian food
data.text:
10 colleagues and I had a working lunch at Mantra in June. The manager provided semi-private space on the second floor. We ate off the $10 lunch buffet. It says a lot about the place that my boss, who is Indian, and I, who has have very little exposure to Indian cuisine, were both very satisfied with lunch. There were two soups, neither of which rocked my world, salad and probably a dozen hot entrees. I was able to find stuff that was deeply flavorful but not so exotic that it became distracting while she declared several dishes "authentic and delicious." The hot carrot pudding as a special treat, a dessert that I'd never encountered but I'm now experimenting with at home.

And I'm looking forward to taking my suspicious 15-year-old there for lunch; I think he's going to find a lot to like. I did.

data.title: Good Quality Food and Clean Restaurant
data.text: I ate lunch here today and wanted to have the buffet, but found that on Holidays the buffet is not served. So I ordered from the menu and asked for mild seasoning. It came as ordered and tasted really good but for me it was too small of a serving. I would have been more satisfied if the serving was more and for the price I thought it should have been. I would go back here again though to try the buffet at lunch.

data.title: Good Tikka Masala
data.text: I don't know if there's a real good Indian restaurant in the Quad Cities, when I crave Masala, this is where I go.

data.title: Nice Atmosphere, Food OK
data.text: The decor is very nice. I have gone twice with co-workers for lunch, good place for this. I don't think this my food.  I know some people that really like this place. Buffet not worth $10 for me. I ate mostly the bread/pita and rice. I enjoy trying new foods. It was fun once. There aren't that many choices downtown.. The lentil soup was ok. The other, "my friends called it butter soup" wasn't for me. There was fresh fruit and salad. Lots of potato and pea dishes. Mostly same food both times. Service was fine.

data.title: New To Indian Cuisine
data.text:
Stopped here for lunch with a friend who comes quite a bit. I am admittedly ignorant when it comes to Indian Cuisine. I wanted to try as many things as possible, and the lunch buffet was an affordable way to do some sampling.

 I was pleased with the staff, who were friendly, accommodating, and always busy checking/filling the buffet. The atmosphere was quiet and comfortable. The food was really very good.

 Apologies, but due to my inexperience, I can't name many of the dishes I had eaten, but they have a nice mix of chicken dishes including a very nice chicken and spinach dish with a great cumin flavor, tandoori chicken, and a really tasty curry chicken entree. I had never eaten naan before, was a nice crisp thin pita like bread that was awesome for eating with the various sauces and a great way to put a flavor breaker between dishes. 

 There was a great selection of sides, 2 hot soups, and some really nice fresh cut salad. After my meal, I was able to get fresh melon, perfectly ripened pineapple and other mixed fruit. They had a rice pudding my friend said was great, but I was too full to try anything else. :)  

 I think I am hooked on Indian food and the wonderful array of delicious spices and textures, am looking forward to going back.

data.title: Awesome
data.text: This place is great. The atmosphere is lovely and the food is incredible. I went there for the lunch buffet and it was great. My only complaint was that there were limited options for vegetarian food, which is unusual for an Indian restaurant. But my boyfriend, who appreciates a good chicken curry, really loved the meat dishes.

data.title: won't go back
data.text: I read reviews for this restaurant and had to try it out. I won't go back. Food was just OK. we had the set-priced dinner for 2.  the mulligatawny soup was just a very thin broth and the chicken soup was more like tomato soup. Both didn't have much flavor. Had tandorri chicken. It was good. they must serve this as an appertizer, cuz the waiter wanted to box it up ten minutes  before we got the Naan bread, rice, Lamb and Chicken masala!

data.title: Indian food in the Quad Cities
data.text: This is about the only place to get Indian food in the Quad Cities.  The place is not fancy, but the food is very good.  The cook will spice the dishes to your preference.  Great place to eat on a budget.

data.title: Frequest visitor
data.text:
I'm always pleased eating at Mantra (which is at least two times per month). The servers are always so gracious, helpful, and kind. They recognize me now when I come in!

The food is exceptional; the lunch buffet is a must. They serve two soups, at least two meat entrees, salad, chutneys, desserts, and veg entrees. Flavorful and high quality saag paneer (my husband loves theirs the best!) and I frequently crave their mulligatawny soup.

data.title: Best Indian food we've had.
data.text: First time visiting but definitely not the last. Good was excellent, service was first taste service and great prices!

data.title: Great food and service
data.text: I really enjoyed the Indian cuisine at this downtown restaurant.  We had great spice in the aloo ghobi and in the chicken tikka masala.  The garlic naan was magical in its aroma and freshness.  Definitely worth the visit!

data.title: A great value
data.text:
I've been here a few times now, and have not left disappointed.  The staff is very friendly, and helpful.  They never tire of answering questions about unknown facets of the Indian cuisine.  

The food is always great, and tasty.  The environment is always clean.  The owner and manager have always come out and greeted my party when we are dining.  You can tell that they care about the service, and the customer.

data.title: Indian food
data.text: Delicious Indian food; go here for lunch buffet, best deal and try things you've not had before; you won't be sorry!

data.title: Great good but don't ask what we had
data.text: We've had Indian food a half dozen times so we're still novices. Went for the buffet for $10 each and everything we tried was great. Some spice but not too hot. We never remember the names of what we like so the buffet was easier than trying to order off a menu.
